generif.text: This gene fuses with an intronless gene in renal tumors harboring the t(6;11)(p21;q13) chromosome translocation.
TFEB protein is a highly sensitive and specific diagnostic marker for these renal neoplasms
TFEB in the neoplastic tissue compared to the normal sample, supports that the fusion gene does not encode for a chimeric protein but causes an upregulation of the wild-type TFEB.
overexpression of TFE3 or TFEB in renal cell carinomas activates the expression of genes normally regulated by microphthalmia transcription factor in other cell types.
TFEB is identified as a master regulator of lysosomal biogenesis and function.

study found that starvation activates a transcriptional program controlling major steps of the autophagic pathway; TFEB, a master gene for lysosomal biogenesis, coordinated this program by driving expression of autophagy and lysosomal genes
TFEB coordinates the expression of 471 genes network involved in the early and late steps of lysosomal biogenesis.

TFEB transcriptionally regulates lysosomal exocytosis both by inducing the release of intracellular Ca2+ through its target gene MCOLN1 and by increasing the population of lysosomes ready to fuse with the plasma membrane.
mTORC1 regulates the nuclear localization of TFEB by promoting phosphorylation in the serine-rich motif.
When nutrients are present, phosphorylation of TFEB by mTORC1 inhibits TFEB activity.
Describes the clinical and histopathologic features of TFE3 and TFEB translocation renal cell carcinoma.
Active TFEB also associates with late endosomal/lysosomal membranes through interaction with the LAMTOR/RRAG/MTORC1 complex.
The transcription factor TFEB links mTORC1 signaling to transcriptional control of lysosome homeostasis.
TFEB is activated by PGC1-alpha and promotes reduction of htt aggregation and neurotoxicity in a mouse model of Huntington disease.
TFEB gene transfer is a novel strategy for treatment of liver disease of alpha-1-anti-trypsin deficiency.
findings identify TFEB as a specific regulator of lysosomal proteostasis and suggest that TFEB may be used as a therapeutic target to rescue enzyme homeostasis in LSDs.

lysosomal exocytosis induced by TFEB nuclear translocation is required not only for plasma membrane repair and lysosomal content secretion, but also for the recruitment of glycohydrolases on the cell surface.
HPbetaCD administration promotes transcription factor EB-mediated clearance of proteolipid aggregates that accumulate due to inefficient activity of the lysosome-autophagy system
Review of the role of gene fusions involving TFE3 and TFEB in carcinogenesis in sporadic renal cell carcinoma.
We examined the transcriptional regulation of autophagy and observed a functionally significant physical interaction between TFEB and AR in spinal and bulbar muscular atrophy.
Results showed the amplification of TFEB locus was found only in the aggressive t(6;11) Renal Cell Carcinoma.

Data show that drug-induced TFEB-associated lysosomal biogenesis is a determinant of multidrug resistance (MDR) and suggest that circumvention of lysosomal drug sequestration is a strategy to overcome chemoresistance.
Lysosomal calcium signaling regulates autophagy through calcineurin and TFEB.
TFEB modulates autophagic clearance of alpha-syn
RIP1 represses basal autophagy in part due to its ability to regulate the TFEB transcription factor;RIP1 activates ERK, which negatively regulates TFEB though phosphorylation of serine 142
a virus modulating TFEB localization and helps to explain how HIV modulates autophagy to promote its own replication and cell survival
TFEB was found to regulate MuRF1 expression in Angiotensin II-induced skeletal muscle atrophy.
during mitophagy TFEB translocates to the nucleus and displays transcriptional activity in a PINK1- and Parkin-dependent manner.
Silencing of TFEB with siRNAs in lung cancer cell lines resulted in reduced migration ability.
TFEB1 overexpression is associated with drug resistance of ovarian cancer.

This study demonstrated that transcription factor EB (TFEB) regulate the lysosome biogenesis in neurons of APP/PS1 mice, steady-state levels of APP were reduced, resulting in decreased interstitial fluid Abeta levels and attenuated amyloid deposits
The autophagic response to polystyrene nanoparticles is mediated by TFEB and depends on surface charge.
TFEB and TFE3 are novel components of the integrated stress response
Lack of cystinosin reduced TFEB expression and induced TFEB nuclear translocation.

TFEB and TFE3 collaborate with each other in activated macrophages and microglia to promote efficient autophagy induction, increased lysosomal biogenesis, and transcriptional upregulation of numerous proinflammatory cytokines
TFEB is affected by a novel curcumin analog in vitro and in vivo independent of MTOR inhibition

the central autophagy regulator TFEB is expressed and active in PDAC, but autophagy is sustained after TFEB knockdown, suggesting alternative bypass signaling. TFEB is dispensable for gemcitabine-induced cell death, but inversely correlated with KRAS expression.
Neuronal C-ETS2 senses oxidative stress, activates TFEB transcription, and mediates the upregulation of lysosomal genes.

Overexpression of deacetylated transcription factor EB at K116R mutant in microglia accelerated intracellular fibrillar Amyloid beta-peptide degradation by stimulating lysosomal biogenesis and greatly reduced the deposited amyloid plaques in the brain.

TFEB has attracted a lot of attention owing to its ability to induce the intracellular clearance of pathogenic factors in a variety of murine models of disease, such as Parkinson's and Alzheimer's, suggesting that novel therapeutic strategies could be based on the modulation of TFEB activity.

Findings suggest that TFEB activation in tauopathy model mice stimulates the autophagy-lysosome pathway, resulting in the clearance of PHF-tau and lipofuscins, which in turn may rescue loss of synapses, and learning and memory deficits.

Results demonstrate that TFEB levels and subcellular distribution undergo distinct short-term and long-term control. These findings suggest that the rapid rheostatic response, mediated by mTOR, allows the cell to quickly adapt to metabolic changes, while the long-term, mTOR independent homeostatic response controls the magnitude and duration of TFEB activation, and presumably limits excessive autophagy.

Review of the role of TFEB in lysosome biogenesis, transcriptional and post-transcriptional regulation of TFEB, and TFEB involvement in neurodegenerative disease as a dysregulated factor or as an agent used to promote cellular clearance.
TFEB regulates PER3 expression via glucose-dependent effects on CLOCK/BMAL1

TFEB-amplified renal cell carcinomas represent a distinct molecular subtype of high-grade adult renal cell carcinomas associated with aggressive clinical behavior, variable morphology, and aberrant melanocytic marker expression

cellular vacuolization, represents a condition of profound lysosome stress, and cells sense and respond to this stress by facilitating mTOR-dependent TFEB nucleus translocation in an effort to restore lysosome homeostasis.

Results identify cigarette smoke (CS)-induced accumulation of TFEB in aggresome-bodies as a specific novel mechanism for CS-mediated autophagy-impairment and resulting aggresome-formation and emphysema progression.
Case Report: suggest that extensive sclerosis and ossification may be a less common recurring histology of TFEB-rearrangement renal cell carcinoma.

Studies identified TFEB and TFE3 as master modulators of stress response notably in the lysosomal biogenesis and autophagy with capability to upregulate hundreds of genes involved in intracellular clearance, catabolism, metabolic processes, and cellular homeostasis.

Amplification of chromosome 6p including the TFEB gene is a novel occurrence in renal cell carcinoma, which seems to be associated with an often aggressive and infiltrative tubulopapillary growth pattern.
Overexpression of TFEB is associated with Breast Cancer.
These data reveal a novel mechanism of TFEB regulation by MTORC1 essential for lysosomal biogenesis.

Both Danon Disease and glycogen storage disease type II show accumulation and altered localization of VPS15 in autophagy-incompetent fibers. However, TFEB displays a different pattern between these two lysosomal storage diseases

Data suggest that transcription factor EB (TFEB) is a protective transcription factor against endothelial cell inflammation and a potential target for treating atherosclerosis and associated cardiovascular diseases.
Activation of TFEB ameliorates disease phenotypes in a mouse model of Batten disease.

Akt phosphorylates TFEB at Ser467 and represses TFEB nuclear translocation independently of mechanistic target of rapamycin complex 1, a known TFEB inhibitor. Pharmacological inhibition of Akt promotes cellular clearance in cells from patients with a variety of lysosomal diseases.
TFEB is phosphorylated and inactivated by Akt.
This study reveals a critical link between two keys factors in tumourigenesis and autophagy, and suggests a potential important role of p53-TFEB signaling axis in lung cancer.
review of role linking cellular stress to immune response

Consistent with reduced transcription factor EB (TFEB) activity, accumulation of phosphorylated TFEB in STUB1-deficient cells resulted in reduced autophagy and reduced mitochondrial biogenesis. These studies reveal that the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway participates in regulating autophagy and lysosomal functions by regulating the activity of TFEB.

Data suggest that PEG3 is required for TFEB induction and nuclear translocation in a VEGFR2- and AMPK-dependent manner for decorin/decorin receptor-evoked autophagy. (PEG3 = paternally expressed 3 protein; TFEB = transcription factor EB; VEGFR2 = vascular endothelial growth factor receptor-2; AMPK = AMP-activated protein kinase)
these data suggest that the TFEB/TMEM55B/JIP4 pathway coordinates lysosome movement in response to a variety of stress conditions.

Taken together, these data demonstrate that ATO induces osteosarcoma cell death via inducing excessive autophagy, which is mediated through the ROS-TFEB pathway. The present study provides a new anti-tumor mechanism of ATO treatment in osteosarcoma.
TFEB knockdown reduces invasion and migration of cancer cells, likely through lysosomal regulation. Taken together, TFEB influences cell invasion and migration of oral squamous cell carcinomas.
Data suggest that the effects of Alpha-TFEB gene fusion are specific in renal cell carcinoma, which results in the overexpression of a native TFEB protein and then promotes cell canceration.
Our data identify TFEB as not only a potential target for preventing alpha-synuclein transmission, but also a critical factor for iron-induced alpha-synuclein aggregation and transmission
MAP4K3 is identified as an amino acid-dependent regulator of autophagy through its phosphorylation of transcription factor EB (TFEB), a transcriptional activator of autophagy.
TFEB was activated shortly after Acinetobacter baumannii infection, and is required for its persistence within host cells.
altering the nuclear export of HLH-30/TFEB can regulate autophagy.

In this review, the authors delineate the current understanding of how TFEB dysregulation is involved in neurodegeneration. Because TFEB is a central node in defining autophagy activation status, efforts at understanding the basis for TFEB dysfunction are yielding insights into how TFEB might be targeted for therapeutic application, which may represent an exciting opportunity for the development of a treatment modality.
This study unveils a positive role of TRIM37 in regulating the MTORC1-TFEB axis.
The transcription factor EB (TFEB) nuclear export signal (NES) integrates carbon (glucose) and nitrogen (amino acid) availability by controlling TFEB flux through a nuclear import-export cycle.
TMEM106B drives lung cancer metastasis by inducing TFEB-dependent lysosome synthesis and secretion of cathepsins.
TFEB acetylation plays an important role in determining its transcriptional activity, lysosomal function and autophagy in cancer cells.
data on TFEB nucleo-cytoplasmic shuttling suggest an unpredicted role of mTOR in nuclear export.

our results demonstrated that procyanidin B2 attenuated FFAs-induced hepatic steatosis through regulating TFEB-mediated lysosomal pathway and redox state, which had important implications that modulation of TFEB might be a potential therapeutic strategy for hepatic steatosis and procyanidin B2 could represent a promising novel agent in the prevention and treatment of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
TFEB promotes expression of endocytic genes and increases rates of cellular endocytosis during homeostatic baseline and starvation conditions.
The activity of TFEB in chondrocyte is involved in OA development.

a rapid export of TFEB from the nucleus to the cytosol occurs upon relief of mTORC1 inhibition, suggesting that dephosphorylated TFEB constantly travels between the nucleus and the cytosol, acting as a rapidly responding sensor of mTORC1 activity.
This study unravels the role of calcineurin in the dephosphorylation of TFEB as well as the involvement of TFEB in lysosomal exocytosis, respectively.

Results indicate that transcription factor EB modulates amyloid beta production not only by increasing alpha-secretase processing of amyloid beta precursor protein through ADAM10 upregulation but also by augmenting beta-C-terminal fragment levels possibly via altered proteasome-mediated catabolism.
our study highlights the potential of PE supplementation as a physiological therapy to modulate TFEB activity to alleviate mitochondrial dysfunction in aging and mitochondrial-related diseases.

RNA sequencing of TFEB-overexpressed human umbilical vein ECs suggested TFEB inhibits NF-kappaB (nuclear factor-kappa B) signaling. Inhibition of IKK by PS-1145 abolished TFEB silencing-induced inflammation in human umbilical vein ECs.
Cross-regulation of defective endolysosome trafficking and enhanced autophagy through TFEB in UNC13D deficiency.

PR137B-knockout cells exhibited defective autophagy and an expanded lysosome compartment, similar to Rag-knockout cells. Like zebrafish RagA mutants, GPR137B-mutant zebrafish had upregulated TFEB target gene expression and an expanded lysosome compartment in microglia.

Prolonged treatment with progestin R5020 upregulates autophagy in MCF-7 human breast cancer cells via a novel interplay between progesterone receptor B and TFEB. It upregulates TFEB gene expression and protein levels in a PRB-dependent manner and enhances the co-recruitment of PRB and TFEB to each other to facilitate TFEB nuclear localization. In the nucleus, TFEB induces the expression of autophagy genes.
Our findings show disease-specific deregulation of TFEB and SCARB2 expression affecting alternative promoter usage and alternative splicing in Lewy body diseases
SCD1 activation impedes foam cell formation by inducing lipophagy in oxLDL-treated human vascular smooth muscle cells.
nutrient stress induces the protein expression of both MITF and TFEB in ARPE-19 cells.

Our findings reveal TFEB-driven autophagy is required for TGF-beta induced migration and metastasis of PC cells by promoting endocytosis of Itgalpha5beta1 and focal adhesion disassembly through the TGF-beta-TFEB-RAB5A axis.
these studies identify YY1 as a novel cotranscription factor of TFEB in regulating autophagy and lysosomal functions and suggest YY1 could be a therapeutic target in cancer treatment
TFEB activates Nrf2 by repressing its E3 ubiquitin ligase DCAF11 and promoting phosphorylation of p62.

6p21.1 amplified renal tumors show increased TFEB expression but not as much as t(6;11) tumors. Findings correlate with the less consistent/diffuse expression of downstream markers of TFEB activation (cathepsin K, melan A, HMB45) seen in the amplified neoplasms, suggesting that the aggressive biological behavior of 6p21.1 amplified renal tumors might be secondary to other genes at the 6p21.1 locus that are co-amplified.
The signaling axis of Rac1-TFEB regulates autophagy and tumorigenesis.
TFEB activation in macrophages attenuates postmyocardial infarction ventricular dysfunction independently of ATG5-mediated autophagy.

retromer expression is upregulated by transcription factor EB (TFEB) and other members of the MiTF/TFE family of transcription factors through association with CLEAR elements in the promoters of the retromer genes VPS35 and VPS26A
Restriction of intracellular Salmonella replication by restoring TFEB-mediated xenophagy.
Report morphological features of Xp11 renal cell carcinoma with TFEB fusion variants.

The authors data provide novel evidence towards the involvement of TFEB in DNA damage repair induced by doxorubicin treatment and apoptosis regulation independent of its lysosomal effects in triple-negative breast cancer cells.
Critical Role of TFEB-Mediated Lysosomal Biogenesis in Alcohol-Induced Pancreatitis in Mice and Humans.
A food-responsive switch modulates TFEB and autophagy, and determines susceptibility to coxsackievirus infection and pancreatitis.
Cyclodextrin Prevents Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm via Activation of Vascular Smooth Muscle Cell Transcription Factor EB.
TFEB Modulates p21/WAF1/CIP1 during the DNA Damage Response.
The Transcription Factor EB Reduces the Intraneuronal Accumulation of the Beta-Secretase-Derived APP Fragment C99 in Cellular and Mouse Alzheimer's Disease Models.
TFEB is a master regulator of tumor-associated macrophages in breast cancer.
The unfolded protein response regulates hepatic autophagy by sXBP1-mediated activation of TFEB.
mTORC1-dependent TFEB nucleus translocation and pro-survival autophagy induced by zeolitic imidazolate framework-8.
Lysosomal dysfunction of corneal fibroblasts underlies the pathogenesis of Granular Corneal Dystrophy Type 2 and can be rescued by TFEB.
An FGF15/19-TFEB regulatory loop controls hepatic cholesterol and bile acid homeostasis.
MiT/TFE factors control ER-phagy via transcriptional regulation of FAM134B.
Nuclear miR-30b-5p suppresses TFEB-mediated lysosomal biogenesis and autophagy.
Transcription factor EB and TFE3: new metabolic coordinators mediating adaptive responses to exercise in skeletal muscle?
MITF and TFEB cross-regulation in melanoma cells.
Programmed cell death 4 modulates lysosomal function by inhibiting TFEB translation.
TFEB Transcriptional Responses Reveal Negative Feedback by BHLHE40 and BHLHE41.
TFEB rearranged renal cell carcinoma. A clinicopathologic and molecular study of 13 cases. Tumors harboring MALAT1-TFEB, ACTB-TFEB, and the novel NEAT1-TFEB translocations constantly express PDL1.
Multifaceted activities of transcription factor EB in cancer onset and progression.
Inositol Polyphosphate Multikinase Inhibits Liquid-Liquid Phase Separation of TFEB to Negatively Regulate Autophagy Activity.
Endothelial TFEB (Transcription Factor EB) Improves Glucose Tolerance via Upregulation of IRS (Insulin Receptor Substrate) 1 and IRS2.
TFEB/Mitf links impaired nuclear import to autophagolysosomal dysfunction in C9-ALS.
A conserved cysteine-based redox mechanism sustains TFEB/HLH-30 activity under persistent stress.
Mechanism and restoration strategy of lysosomal abnormalities induced by urinary protein overload in proximal tubule epithelial cells.
Transcription factor EBmediated autophagy promotes dermal fibroblast differentiation and collagen production by regulating endoplasmic reticulum stress and autophagydependent secretion.
Autophagy-Dependent Increased ADAM10 Mature Protein Induced by TFEB Overexpression Is Mediated Through PPARalpha.
The important role of TFEB in autophagy-lysosomal pathway and autophagy-related diseases: a systematic review.
Coxsackievirus B3 targets TFEB to disrupt lysosomal function.
TP53/p53-FBXO22-TFEB controls basal autophagy to govern hormesis.
Neurodegenerative VPS41 variants inhibit HOPS function and mTORC1-dependent TFEB/TFE3 regulation.
TFEB links MYC signaling to epigenetic control of myeloid differentiation and acute myeloid leukemia.
Suppression of lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase impacts the modulation of transcription factor EB translocation in pancreatic cancer.
Fenofibrate, a PPARalpha agonist, reduces hepatic fat accumulation through the upregulation of TFEB-mediated lipophagy.
Diagnostic utility of one-stop fusion gene panel to detect TFE3/TFEB gene rearrangement and amplification in renal cell carcinomas.
TFEB-mediated endolysosomal activity controls human hematopoietic stem cell fate.
TFEB Signalling-Related MicroRNAs and Autophagy.
TFEB phosphorylation on Serine 211 is induced by autophagy in human synovial fibroblasts and by p62/SQSTM1 overexpression in HEK293 cells.
TFEB insufficiency promotes cardiac hypertrophy by blocking autophagic degradation of GATA4.
Association between TFEB gene polymorphism, gene-environment interaction, and fatty liver disease: A case-control study in China.
Transcription factor EB enhances autophagy and ameliorates palmitate-induced insulin resistance at least partly via upregulating AMPK activity in skeletal muscle cells.
TFEB, SIRT1, CARM1, Beclin-1 expression and PITX2 methylation in breast cancer chemoresistance: a retrospective study.
Renal Cell Carcinoma in Tuberous Sclerosis Complex.
A splicing variant of TFEB negatively regulates the TFEB-autophagy pathway.
Downregulation of AMPK dependent FOXO3 and TFEB involves in the inhibition of autophagy in diabetic cataract.
TFEB-dependent autophagy is involved in scavenger receptor OLR1/LOX-1-mediated tumor progression.
TFEB Regulates ATP7B Expression to Promote Platinum Chemoresistance in Human Ovarian Cancer Cells.
Vascular smooth muscle cell-derived hydrogen sulfide promotes atherosclerotic plaque stability via TFEB (transcription factor EB)-mediated autophagy.
Disrupting the MYC-TFEB Circuit Impairs Amino Acid Homeostasis and Provokes Metabolic Anergy.
TFEB- and TFE3-dependent autophagy activation supports cancer proliferation in the absence of centrosomes.
Comprehensive study of nine novel cases of TFEB-amplified renal cell carcinoma: an aggressive tumour with frequent PDL1 expression.
Transcription factor EB controls both motogenic and mitogenic cell activities.
Phosphoproteomic Analysis of FLCN Inactivation Highlights Differential Kinase Pathways and Regulatory TFEB Phosphoserines.
TRPML1 and TFEB, an Intimate Affair.
TFEB in Alzheimer's disease: From molecular mechanisms to therapeutic implications.
FGF21 alleviates microvascular damage following limb ischemia/reperfusion injury by TFEB-mediated autophagy enhancement and anti-oxidative response.
Loss of transcription factor EB dysregulates the G1/S transition and DNA replication in mammary epithelial cells.
p38 MAPK-dependent phosphorylation of TFEB promotes monocyte-to-macrophage differentiation.
Endothelial TFEB signaling-mediated autophagic disturbance initiates microglial activation and cognitive dysfunction.
TFEB-mediated lysosomal exocytosis alleviates high-fat diet-induced lipotoxicity in the kidney.
Structure of the lysosomal mTORC1-TFEB-Rag-Ragulator megacomplex.
Transcription factor EB regulates phosphatidylinositol-3-phosphate levels that control lysosome positioning in the bladder cancer model.
EGR1 drives cell proliferation by directly stimulating TFEB transcription in response to starvation.
TFEB-dependent lysosome biogenesis is required for senescence.
TFEB and TFE3 drive kidney cystogenesis and tumorigenesis.
RagD auto-activating mutations impair MiT/TFE activity in kidney tubulopathy and cardiomyopathy syndrome.
Dissecting the multifaced function of transcription factor EB (TFEB) in human diseases: From molecular mechanism to pharmacological modulation.
Transcription factor EB: A potential integrated network regulator in metabolic-associated cardiac injury.
LncRNA XXYLT1-AS2 promotes tumor progression via autophagy inhibition through ubiquitinated degradation of TFEB in hepatocellular carcinoma.
FBXL5 promotes lipid accumulation in alcoholic fatty liver disease by promoting the ubiquitination and degradation of TFEB.
A candidate prognostic biomarker: TFEB inhibits tumor progression via elevating CDKN1A in bladder cancer.
ABCG2 is an itaconate exporter that limits antibacterial innate immunity by alleviating TFEB-dependent lysosomal biogenesis.
TFEB regulates the odontoblastic differentiation of dental pulp stem cells by promoting a positive feedback loop between mitophagy and glycolysis.
Transcription factor EB-mediated autophagy affects cell migration and inhibits apoptosis to promote endometriosis.
A SPLICS reporter reveals [Formula: see text]-synuclein regulation of lysosome-mitochondria contacts which affects TFEB nuclear translocation.
Impaired TFEB-mediated autophagy-lysosome fusion promotes tubular cell cycle G2/M arrest and renal fibrosis by suppressing ATP6V0C expression and interacting with SNAREs.
Altered TFEB subcellular localization in nigral neurons of subjects with incidental, sporadic and GBA-related Lewy body diseases.
TFEB regulates dendritic cell antigen presentation to modulate immune balance in asthma.
Muscle-bone cross-talk through the FNIP1-TFEB-IGF2 axis is associated with bone metabolism in human and mouse.
TFEB safeguards trophoblast syncytialization in humans and mice.

cellular response to amino acid starvation
positive regulation of transcription by RNA polymerase II

name: transcription factor EB

reactome.name: Transcriptional and post-translational regulation of MITF-M expression and activity

wikipathways.name: PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway and therapeutic opportunities

summary: Enables DNA-binding transcription factor activity; enzyme binding activity; and transcription cis-regulatory region binding activity. Involved in several processes, including cellular response to amino acid starvation; lysosome localization; and positive regulation of autophagy. Located in cytosol; lysosomal membrane; and nucleoplasm. [provided by Alliance of Genome Resources, Apr 2022]
